001package squidpony.squidgrid.gui.gdx;
002
003import com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Color;
004import com.badlogic.gdx.math.MathUtils;
005import squidpony.squidmath.NumberTools;
006
007import static squidpony.squidgrid.gui.gdx.SColor.floatGet;
008import static squidpony.squidgrid.gui.gdx.SColor.lerpFloatColorsBlended;
009
010/**
011 * Pre-made FloatFilter classes that you can use to filter colors without producing extra Color objects.
012 * <br>
013 * Created by Tommy Ettinger on 7/22/2018.
014 */
015public final class FloatFilters {
016    private FloatFilters() {
017        // don't build me!
018    }
019
020    /**
021     * Wraps the functionality of {@link SColor#toEditedFloat(float, float, float, float, float)} so it can be called as
022     * a FloatFilter, adding values to hue, saturation, and value (clamping saturation and value and wrapping hue).
023     * Hue is in the 0.0 to 1.0 range, as SquidLib handles it, instead of libGDX's 0 to 360 range.
024     */
025    public static class HSVFilter extends FloatFilter {
026        public float hueAddend, saturationAddend, valueAddend;
027
028        public HSVFilter(float saturation, float value) {
029            this(0f, saturation, value);
030        }
031
032        public HSVFilter(float hueAdd, float saturationAdd, float valueAdd) {
033            hueAddend = hueAdd;
034            saturationAddend = saturationAdd;
035            valueAddend = valueAdd;
036        }
037
038        /**
039         * Takes a packed float color and produces a potentially-different packed float color that this FloatFilter edited.
040         *
041         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
042         * @return a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
043         */
044        @Override
045        public float alter(float color) {
046            return SColor.toEditedFloat(color, hueAddend, saturationAddend, valueAddend, 0f);
047        }
048    }
049
050    /**
051     * Changes all colors this alters to have the same hue as, and a closer saturation to, a target color given in the
052     * constructor, as well as optionally multiplying saturation of the result and/or adding lightness/value. A good
053     * example usage of this is to make a sepia-tone effect with
054     * {@code new FloatFilters.ColorizeFilter(SColor.CLOVE_BROWN, 0.6f, 0.0f)}.
055     */
056    public static class ColorizeFilter extends FloatFilter {
057        public float targetCb, targetCr, lumaAddend;
058
059        public ColorizeFilter(float color) {
060            this(color, 1f, 0f);
061        }
062
063        public ColorizeFilter(Color color) {
064            this(color.toFloatBits(), 1f, 0f);
065        }
066
067        public ColorizeFilter(Color color, float chromaMul, float lumaAdd) {
068            this(color.toFloatBits(), chromaMul, lumaAdd);
069        }
070
071        public ColorizeFilter(float color, float chromaMul, float lumaAdd) {
072            targetCb = SColor.chromaBOfFloat(color) * chromaMul;
073            targetCr = SColor.chromaROfFloat(color) * chromaMul;
074            lumaAddend = lumaAdd;
075        }
076
077        /**
078         * Takes a packed float color and produces a potentially-different packed float color that this FloatFilter edited.
079         *
080         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
081         * @return a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
082         */
083        @Override
084        public float alter(float color) {
085            final int bits = NumberTools.floatToIntBits(color);
086            return SColor.floatGetYCbCr((bits & 0x000000ff) * (0x1.010102p-8f  * 0.299f) +
087                    (bits & 0x0000ff00) * (0x1.010102p-16f * 0.587f) +
088                    (bits & 0x00ff0000) * (0x1.010102p-24f * 0.114f),
089                    targetCb, targetCr,
090                    ((bits & 0xfe000000) >>> 24) * 0x1.020408p-8f);
091        }
092    }
093
094    /**
095     * A FloatFilter that alters primarily-red and primarily-green colors so they can be more easily be distinguished by
096     * people with at least some forms of red-green color-blindness (deuteranopia should be handled well, protanopia
097     * very well, and tritanopia may not benefit at all). Causes reds to be darkened and greens to be lightened if the
098     * other of the pair is not present in similar quantities (which is the case for yellows and blues).
099     */
100    public static class DistinctRedGreenFilter extends FloatFilter {
101        /**
102         * Constructs a DistinctRedGreenFilter. This class is a simple wrapper around a function that doesn't need
103         * member variables, so there should be little overhead with this filter.
104         */
105        public DistinctRedGreenFilter() {
106        }
107
108        /**
109         * Takes a packed float color and produces a potentially-different packed float color that this FloatFilter edited.
110         *
111         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
112         * @return a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
113         */
114        @Override
115        public float alter(float color) {
116//            final int bits = NumberTools.floatToIntBits(color),
117//                    r = bits & 0xFF, g = bits >>> 8 & 0xFF, b = bits >>> 16 & 0xFF, a = bits >>> 24,
118//                    diff = g - r;
119//            if (diff > 101)
120//                return floatGet(Math.min(1f, 0x1.010102p-16f * r * (203 + (diff >> 1))),
121//                        Math.min(1f, 0x1.010102p-16f * g * (228 + (diff >> 1))),
122//                        Math.min(1f, 0x1.010102p-16f * b * (203 + (diff >> 1))),
123//                        0x1.010102p-8f * a);
124//            else if (diff < -75)
125//                return floatGet(Math.min(1f, 0x1.010102p-16f * r * (152 - diff)),
126//                        Math.min(1f, 0x1.010102p-16f * g * (177 - diff)),
127//                        Math.min(1f, 0x1.010102p-16f * b * (177 - diff)),
128//                        0x1.010102p-8f * a);
129//            else
130//                return color;
131            final int bits = NumberTools.floatToIntBits(color);
132            final float opacity = (bits >>> 24 & 0xFE) * 0.003937008f;
133            float luma = (
134                    (bits & 0x000000ff) * (0x1.010102p-8f * 0.299f) +
135                            (bits & 0x0000ff00) * (0x1.010102p-16f * 0.587f) +
136                            (bits & 0x00ff0000) * (0x1.010102p-24f * 0.114f));
137            float chromaB = (
138                    (bits & 0x000000ff) * (0x1.010102p-8f * -0.168736f) +
139                            (bits & 0x0000ff00) * (0x1.010102p-16f * -0.331264f) +
140                            (bits & 0x00ff0000) * (0x1.010102p-24f * 0.5f));
141            float chromaR = (
142                    (bits & 0x000000ff) * (0x1.010102p-8f * 0.5f) +
143                            (bits & 0x0000ff00) * (0x1.010102p-16f * -0.418688f) +
144                            (bits & 0x00ff0000) * (0x1.010102p-24f * -0.081312f));
145            if(chromaB < -0.05f)
146            {
147                float theta = NumberTools.atan2(chromaR, chromaB);
148                float dist = (float) Math.sqrt(chromaB * chromaB + chromaR * chromaR);
149                if(theta >= 0f)
150                {
151                    theta *= 0.5f;
152                    luma += theta * 0.15f;
153                    theta += 0.7853981633974483f;
154                }
155                else
156                {
157                    theta *= 0.4f;
158                    luma += theta * 0.225f;
159                    theta -= 0.9424778335276408f;
160                }
161                chromaR = MathUtils.sin(theta) * dist;
162                chromaB = MathUtils.cos(theta) * dist;
163            }
164            return floatGet(MathUtils.clamp(luma + chromaR * 1.402f, 0f, 1f),
165                    MathUtils.clamp(luma - chromaB * 0.344136f - chromaR * 0.714136f, 0f, 1f),
166                    MathUtils.clamp(luma + chromaB * 1.772f, 0f, 1f),
167                    opacity);
168
169        }
170    }
171
172    /**
173     * A FloatFilter that makes no changes to the colors given to it; useful as a default for when no filter is wanted.
174     */
175    public static class IdentityFilter extends FloatFilter {
176        /**
177         * Takes a packed float color and returns it un-edited.
178         *
179         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
180         * @return a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
181         */
182        @Override
183        public float alter(float color) {
184            return color;
185        }
186    }
187
188    /**
189     * A static constant of the one possible IdentityFilter, to avoid needing to make duplicates.
190     * IdentityFilter makes no changes to the colors given to it.
191     */
192    public static final IdentityFilter identityFilter = new IdentityFilter();
193
194    /**
195     * A FloatFilter that makes all colors given to it grayscale, using only their luma as calculated by
196     * {@link SColor#lumaOfFloat(float)} as the lightness (it does also preserve alpha transparency).
197     */
198    public static class GrayscaleFilter extends FloatFilter {
199        /**
200         * Takes a packed float color and produces a grayscale packed float color that this FloatFilter edited.
201         * Uses the luma calculation from {@link SColor#lumaOfFloat(float)} instead of the value calculation from
202         * {@link SColor#valueOfFloat(float)}; luma tends to be more visually-accurate on modern monitors.
203         *
204         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
205         * @return a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
206         */
207        @Override
208        public float alter(float color) {
209            final int bits = NumberTools.floatToIntBits(color);
210            color = (bits & 0x000000ff) * (0x1.010102p-8f * 0.299f) +
211                    (bits & 0x0000ff00) * (0x1.010102p-16f * 0.587f) +
212                    (bits & 0x00ff0000) * (0x1.010102p-24f * 0.114f);
213            return floatGet(color, color, color, (bits >>> 24 & 0xFE) * 0.003937008f);
214        }
215    }
216
217    /**
218     * Like {@link HSVFilter}, but edits its input colors in YCbCr color space, and multiplies rather than adds.
219     * Y is luma, and affects how bright the color is (luma 1 is white, luma 0 is black). Cb is Chroma(blue) amd Cr is
220     * Chroma(red), two inter-related channels that determine the hue and vividness of a specific color. When Cb and Cr
221     * are both 0, the color is grayscale. When Cb is 0.5 and Cr is -0.5, the color is blue unless Y is very high or
222     * low. When Cb is -0.5 and Cr is 0.5, the color is red with the same caveats re: Y. When Cb and Cr are both -0.5,
223     * the color is green (same caveats), and when both are 0.5, the color is purple. When Y is 0.5, Cb and Cr form a
224     * graph like this:
225     * <br>
226     * <img src="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/YCbCr-CbCr_Y50.png/240px-YCbCr-CbCr_Y50.png" />
227     * <br>
228     * Valid values for Cb and Cr are from -0.5 to 0.5 at the widest part of the range (it shrinks as Y approaches 0 or
229     * 1), but there aren't really invalid values here because this filter will clamp results with higher or lower
230     * channel values than a color can have. Each of yMul, cbMul, and crMul can have any float value, but yMul should be
231     * positive (unless you want this to only produce solid black). Similarly, cbMul and crMul will not produce
232     * meaningful results if they are very large (either positive or negative); it's recommended to use values between
233     * 0.0 and 1.0 for both if you want to desaturate colors or values somewhat greater than 1.0 to oversaturate them.
234     */
235    public static class YCbCrFilter extends FloatFilter {
236        public float yMul, cbMul, crMul;
237
238        public YCbCrFilter(float yMul) {
239            this(yMul, 1f, 1f);
240        }
241
242        public YCbCrFilter(float yMul, float cbMul, float crMul) {
243            this.yMul = yMul;
244            this.cbMul = cbMul;
245            this.crMul = crMul;
246        }
247
248        /**
249         * Takes a packed float color and produces a potentially-different packed float color that this FloatFilter edited.
250         *
251         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
252         * @return a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
253         */
254        @Override
255        public float alter(float color) {
256            final int bits = NumberTools.floatToIntBits(color);
257            final float opacity = (bits >>> 24 & 0xFE) * 0.003937008f;
258            float luma = yMul * (
259                    (bits & 0x000000ff) * (0x1.010102p-8f * 0.299f) +
260                            (bits & 0x0000ff00) * (0x1.010102p-16f * 0.587f) +
261                            (bits & 0x00ff0000) * (0x1.010102p-24f * 0.114f));
262            final float chromaB = cbMul * (
263                    (bits & 0x000000ff) * (0x1.010102p-8f * -0.168736f) +
264                            (bits & 0x0000ff00) * (0x1.010102p-16f * -0.331264f) +
265                            (bits & 0x00ff0000) * (0x1.010102p-24f * 0.5f));
266            final float chromaR = crMul * (
267                    (bits & 0x000000ff) * (0x1.010102p-8f * 0.5f) +
268                            (bits & 0x0000ff00) * (0x1.010102p-16f * -0.418688f) +
269                            (bits & 0x00ff0000) * (0x1.010102p-24f * -0.081312f));
270            return floatGet(MathUtils.clamp(luma + chromaR * 1.402f, 0f, 1f),
271                    MathUtils.clamp(luma - chromaB * 0.344136f - chromaR * 0.714136f, 0f, 1f),
272                    MathUtils.clamp(luma + chromaB * 1.772f, 0f, 1f),
273                    opacity);
274        }
275    }
276
277    /**
278     * Like {@link YCbCrFilter}, but edits its input colors in YCoCg color space, or like {@link HSVFilter} except it
279     * doesn't add, it multiplies. Most of the time you should prefer {@link YCbCrFilter} as long as it isn't a
280     * performance bottleneck; this method is faster but less accurate. Y is luminance, ranging from 0 (dark) to 1
281     * (light), and affects how bright the color is, but isn't very accurate perceptually. Co is Chrominance(orange) and
282     * Cg is Chrominance(green) (both range from -0.5 to 0.5), two inter-related channels that determine the hue and
283     * vividness of a specific color. When Co and Cg are both 0, the color is grayscale. When Co is 0.5 and Cg is -0.5,
284     * the color is red unless Y is very high or low. When Co is -0.5 and Cg is 0.5, the color is cyan with the same
285     * caveats re: Y. When Co and Cg are both -0.5, the color is blue (same caveats), and when both are 0.5, the color
286     * is yellow.
287     * <br>
288     * Valid values for Co and Cg are from -0.5 to 0.5 at the widest part of the range (it shrinks as Y approaches 0 or
289     * 1), but there aren't really invalid values here because this filter will clamp results with higher or lower
290     * channel values than a color can have. Each of yMul, coMul, and cgMul can have any float value, but yMul should be
291     * positive (unless you want this to only produce solid black). Similarly, coMul and cgMul will not produce
292     * meaningful results if they are very large (either positive or negative); it's recommended to use values between
293     * 0.0 and 1.0 for both if you want to desaturate colors or values somewhat greater than 1.0 to oversaturate them.
294     */
295    public static class YCoCgFilter extends FloatFilter {
296        public float yMul, coMul, cgMul;
297
298        public YCoCgFilter(float luminanceMul, float orangeMul, float greenMul) {
299            this.yMul = luminanceMul;
300            this.coMul = orangeMul;
301            this.cgMul = greenMul;
302        }
303
304        /**
305         * Takes a packed float color and produces a potentially-different packed float color that this FloatFilter edited.
306         *
307         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
308         * @return a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
309         */
310        @Override
311        public float alter(float color) {
312            final int bits = NumberTools.floatToIntBits(color);
313            final float opacity = (bits >>> 24 & 0xFE) * 0.003937008f;
314            final float y = yMul * (((bits & 0x000000ff) + ((bits & 0x0000ff00) >>> 7) + ((bits & 0x00ff0000) >>> 16)) * 0x1.010102p-10f);
315            final float co = coMul * (((bits & 0x000000ff) - ((bits & 0x00ff0000) >>> 16)) * 0x1.010102p-9f);
316            final float cg = cgMul * ((((bits & 0x0000ff00) >>> 7) - (bits & 0x000000ff) - ((bits & 0x00ff0000) >>> 16)) * 0x1.010102p-10f);
317
318            final float t = y - cg;
319            return floatGet(MathUtils.clamp(t + co, 0f, 1f),
320                    MathUtils.clamp(y + cg, 0f, 1f),
321                    MathUtils.clamp(t - co, 0f, 1f),
322                    opacity);
323        }
324    }
325
326    /**
327     * Like {@link YCbCrFilter} or  {@link YCoCgFilter}, but edits its input colors in YCwCm color space, which is very
328     * similar to YCoCg but has chroma/chrominance components that are useful aesthetically on their own. You may often
329     * prefer {@link YCbCrFilter} because it calculates lightness (luma) more precisely, but the Cb (blue-ness) and Cr
330     * (red-ness) components are less useful for some purposes individually. Y is luminance, ranging from 0 (dark) to 1
331     * (light), and affects how bright the color is, but isn't very accurate perceptually. Cw is Chroma(warm) and
332     * Cm is Chroma(mild) (both range from -1.0 to 1.0), two inter-related channels that determine the hue and vividness
333     * of a specific color. When Cw and Cm are both 0, the color is grayscale. When Cw is 1 and Cm is -1, the color
334     * is red or like red. When Cw is -1 and Cm is 1, the color is green or like green. When Cw and Cm are both -1, the
335     * color is blue or like blue, and when both are 1, the color is roughly yellow or brown (depending on Y).
336     * <br>
337     * Valid values for Cw and Cm are from -1.0 to 1.0, but there aren't really invalid values here because this filter
338     * will clamp results with higher or lower channel values than a color can have. Each of yMul, cwMul, and cmMul can
339     * have any float value, but yMul should be positive (unless you want this to only produce solid black). Similarly,
340     * cwMul and cmMul will not produce meaningful results if they are very large (either positive or negative); it's
341     * recommended to use values between 0.0 and 1.0 for both if you want to desaturate colors or values somewhat
342     * greater than 1.0 to oversaturate them. Unlike {@link YCbCrFilter} and {@link YCoCgFilter}, you can benefit from
343     * setting cwMul independently of the other chroma component, which can be used to emphasize warm vs. cool colors if
344     * cwMul is greater than 1.0, or to de-emphasize that comparison if it is between 0.0 and 1.0. A similar option is
345     * possible for cmMul, but it isn't as clear of an artistic convention; a high cmMul will separate green-and-yellow
346     * colors further from red-purple-and-blue colors. Also unlike the other YCC filters, this allows an additive change
347     * to Y, Cw, and Cm applied after the multiplicative change but before converting to RGB and clamping. This can be
348     * used to make all colors warmer or cooler (such as for volcano or frozen scenes) by adding or subtracting from Cw,
349     * for instance. It can also lighten or darken all colors by changing luma.
350     */
351    public static class YCwCmFilter extends FloatFilter {
352        public float yMul, cwMul, cmMul, yAdd, cwAdd, cmAdd;
353
354        public YCwCmFilter(float yMul, float cwMul, float cmMul) {
355            this(yMul, cwMul, cmMul, 0f, 0f, 0f);
356        }
357        public YCwCmFilter(float yMul, float cwMul, float cmMul, float yAdd, float cwAdd, float cmAdd) {
358            this.yMul = yMul;
359            this.cwMul = cwMul;
360            this.cmMul = cmMul;
361            this.yAdd = yAdd;
362            this.cwAdd = cwAdd;
363            this.cmAdd = cmAdd;
364        }
365
366        /**
367         * Takes a packed float color and produces a potentially-different packed float color that this FloatFilter edited.
368         *
369         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
370         * @return a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
371         */
372        @Override
373        public float alter(float color) {
374            final int bits = NumberTools.floatToIntBits(color);
375            final float opacity = (bits >>> 24 & 0xFE) * 0.003937008f;
376            final float luma = yAdd + yMul * ((bits & 0xFF) * 0x3p-11f + (bits >>> 8 & 0xFF) * 0x1p-9f + (bits >>> 16 & 0xFF) * 0x1p-11f);
377            final float warm = (cwAdd + cwMul * (((bits & 0xFF) - (bits >>> 16 & 0xff)) * 0x1.010102p-8f));
378            final float mild = 0.5f * (cmAdd + cmMul * (((bits >>> 8 & 0xff) - (bits >>> 16 & 0xff)) * 0x1.010102p-8f));
379
380            return floatGet(MathUtils.clamp(luma + warm * 0.625f - mild, 0f, 1f),
381                    MathUtils.clamp(luma + mild - warm * 0.375f, 0f, 1f),
382                    MathUtils.clamp(luma - warm * 0.375f - mild, 0f, 1f),
383                    opacity);
384        }
385    }
386
387    /**
388     * A FloatFilter that chains together one or more FloatFilters one after the next, passing the float output of one
389     * as input to the next until the chain has all been called.
390     */
391    public static class ChainFilter extends FloatFilter {
392        public FloatFilter[] filters;
393
394        /**
395         * Takes a vararg or array of FloatFilter objects and produces a ChainFilter that will call all of them in order
396         * on any color given to this to alter.
397         * @param filters an array or vararg of FloatFilter objects; none can be null
398         */
399        public ChainFilter(FloatFilter... filters)
400        {
401            if(filters == null || filters.length == 0)
402                this.filters = new FloatFilter[]{new IdentityFilter()};
403            this.filters = filters;
404        }
405
406        /**
407         * Takes a packed float color and produces a potentially-different packed float color that this FloatFilter edited.
408         *
409         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
410         * @return a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
411         */
412        @Override
413        public float alter(float color) {
414            for (int i = 0; i < filters.length; i++) {
415                color = filters[i].alter(color);
416            }
417            return color;
418        }
419    }
420
421    /**
422     * A FloatFilter that linearly interpolates (lerps) any color it is given toward a specified color by a specified
423     * amount. Uses {@link SColor#lerpFloatColorsBlended(float, float, float)} to mix a requested color with the target
424     * color, and this means the alpha of the target color affects the amount of change instead of the resulting alpha. 
425     */
426    public static class LerpFilter extends FloatFilter {
427        public float target, amount;
428
429        /**
430         * Builds a LerpFilter with a Color (which will be converted to a packed float color) and an amount as a float.
431         * The amount is how much the target color will affect input colors, from 0f to 1f. If the target color has an
432         * alpha component that is less than 1, then amount is effectively multiplied by that alpha.
433         * @param target a libGDX color; must not be null
434         * @param amount a float that determines how much target will affect an input color; will be clamped between 0f and 1f
435         */
436        public LerpFilter(Color target, float amount) {
437            this.target = target.toFloatBits();
438            this.amount = MathUtils.clamp(amount, 0f, 1f);
439        }
440
441        /**
442         * Builds a LerpFilter with a packed float color and an amount as a float.
443         * The amount is how much the target color will affect input colors, from 0f to 1f. If the target color has an
444         * alpha component that is less than 1, then amount is effectively multiplied by that alpha.
445         * @param target a packed float color; must not be null
446         * @param amount a float that determines how much target will affect an input color; will be clamped between 0f and 1f
447         */
448
449        public LerpFilter(float target, float amount)
450        {
451            this.target = target;
452            this.amount = MathUtils.clamp(amount, 0f, 1f);
453        }
454
455        /**
456         * Takes a packed float color and produces a potentially-different packed float color that this FloatFilter edited.
457         *
458         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
459         * @return a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
460         */
461        @Override
462        public float alter(float color) {
463            return lerpFloatColorsBlended(color, target, amount);
464        }
465    }
466
467    /**
468     * A FloatFilter that linearly interpolates (lerps) any color it is given toward the most-similar of a group of
469     * given colors. Uses {@link SColor#lerpFloatColorsBlended(float, float, float)} to mix a requested color with the
470     * chosen target color, and this means the alpha of the target color affects the amount of change instead of the
471     * resulting alpha. Changing the alpha of the colors this is given can be done easily with
472     * {@link SColor#translucentColor(float, float)}, and this allows you to specify varying amounts to mix by.
473     */
474    public static class MultiLerpFilter extends FloatFilter {
475        public float[] targets;
476        public float amount;
477        /**
478         * Builds a MultiLerpFilter with an array of Color objects (which will be converted to an array of packed float
479         * colors) and an amount as a float. The amount is how much the target colors will affect input colors, from 0f
480         * to 1f. If a target color has an alpha component that is less than 1, then amount is effectively multiplied by
481         * that alpha. If you want to edit the alpha without duplicating Color objects, you can use
482         * {@link SColor#translucentColor(Color, float)} to make a float array to pass to
483         *{@link #MultiLerpFilter(float, float...)}.
484         * @param amount a float that determines how much target will affect an input color; will be clamped between 0f and 1f
485         * @param targets an array of libGDX Color objects; must not be null or empty
486         */
487        public MultiLerpFilter(float amount, Color[] targets) {
488            this.targets = new float[targets.length];
489            for (int i = 0; i < targets.length; i++) {
490                this.targets[i] = targets[i].toFloatBits();
491            }
492            this.amount = MathUtils.clamp(amount, 0f, 1f);
493        }
494
495        /**
496         * Builds a MultiLerpFilter with an array of packed float colors and an amount as a float.
497         * The amount is how much the target color will affect input colors, from 0f to 1f. If the target color has an
498         * alpha component that is less than 1, then amount is effectively multiplied by that alpha.
499         * @param amount a float that determines how much target will affect an input color; will be clamped between 0f and 1f
500         * @param targets an array or vararg of packed float colors; must not be null or empty
501         */
502
503        public MultiLerpFilter(float amount, float... targets)
504        {
505            this.targets = targets;
506            this.amount = MathUtils.clamp(amount, 0f, 1f);
507        }
508
509        /**
510         * Takes a packed float color and produces a potentially-different packed float color that this FloatFilter edited.
511         *
512         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
513         * @return a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
514         */
515        @Override
516        public float alter(float color) {
517            int choice = 0, diff = SColor.difference2(targets[0], color);
518            for (int i = 1; i < targets.length; i++) {
519                if(diff != (diff = Math.min(SColor.difference2(targets[i], color), diff)))
520                    choice = i;
521            }
522            return lerpFloatColorsBlended(color, targets[choice], amount);
523        }
524    }
525
526    /**
527     * A FloatFilter that limits the colors it can return to a fixed palette, and won't return any colors that are
528     * missing from that palette (although it can always return fully-transparent). {@link PaletteReducerFilter} is also
529     * an option; it uses more memory but is faster to look up colors in larger palettes (it has a maximum size of 256
530     * colors, though, which this class doesn't).
531     */
532    public static class PaletteFilter extends FloatFilter {
533        public float[] targets;
534        /**
535         * Builds a PaletteFilter with an array of Color objects that this will choose from. The array will be converted
536         * to an array of packed float colors, and not referenced directly.
537         * @param targets an array of libGDX Color objects; must not be null or empty
538         */
539        public PaletteFilter(final Color[] targets) {
540            this.targets = new float[targets.length];
541            for (int i = 0; i < targets.length; i++) {
542                this.targets[i] = targets[i].toFloatBits();
543            }
544        }
545
546        /**
547         * Builds a PaletteFilter with an array of packed float colors that this will choose from. The array will be
548         * referenced directly, not copied, so if you change the contents of targets, it will be reflected here.
549         * @param targets an array or vararg of packed float colors; must not be null or empty
550         */
551
552        public PaletteFilter(final float... targets)
553        {
554            this.targets = targets;
555        }
556
557        /**
558         * Takes a packed float color and produces a potentially-different packed float color that this FloatFilter edited.
559         *
560         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
561         * @return a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
562         */
563        @Override
564        public float alter(float color) {
565            if(color >= 0f) //if color is halfway-transparent or closer to transparent...
566                return 0f; // return fully transparent
567            int choice = 0, diff = SColor.difference2(targets[0], color);
568            for (int i = 1; i < targets.length; i++) {
569                if(diff != (diff = Math.min(SColor.difference2(targets[i], color), diff)))
570                    choice = i;
571            }
572            return targets[choice];
573        }
574    }
575
576    /**
577     * A FloatFilter that limits the colors it can return to a fixed palette as determined by a {@link PaletteReducer},
578     * and won't return any colors that are missing from that palette (although it can always return fully-transparent).
579     * This is like {@link PaletteFilter} but trades off memory usage (it uses about 33KB to store a large-ish lookup
580     * table) to improve speed on large palettes. This can't use a palette larger than 256 colors (including transparent
581     * almost always).
582     */
583    public static class PaletteReducerFilter extends FloatFilter {
584        public PaletteReducer reducer;
585
586        /**
587         * Builds a PaletteReducerFilter that will use the 256-color (including transparent) DawnBringer Aurora palette.
588         */
589        public PaletteReducerFilter()
590        {
591            reducer = new PaletteReducer();
592        }
593        
594        /**
595         * Builds a PaletteReducerFilter with the given PaletteReducer, which will be referenced without copying. You
596         * can call {@link PaletteReducer#exact(Color[])} or other similar methods before this filter is used to set up
597         * the palette, and this is often done before the PaletteReducer is passed here.
598         * @param palette a PaletteReducer that should have the desired palette set up before this is used
599         */
600        public PaletteReducerFilter(final PaletteReducer palette) {
601            reducer = palette;
602        }
603
604        /**
605         * Builds a PaletteReducerFilter with an array or vararg of libGDX colors (at most 256 colors, and often
606         * starting with a transparent color) that this will choose from. The array will have its contents read but will
607         * not be held onto, so later changes won't affect it.
608         * @param targets an array or vararg of libGDX colors; must not be null
609         */
610
611        public PaletteReducerFilter(final Color... targets)
612        {
613            reducer = new PaletteReducer(targets);
614        }
615
616        /**
617         * Takes a packed float color and produces a potentially-different packed float color that this FloatFilter edited.
618         *
619         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
620         * @return a packed float color, as produced by {@link Color#toFloatBits()}
621         */
622        @Override
623        public float alter(float color) {
624            return reducer.reduceFloat(color);
625        }
626    }
627
628}
